newsitem.title: India: Bombay shares end shade higher on fund buying.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end shade higher on fund buying.

text.p: Bombay shares gained strength by close of trade on Tuesday after a slow start, with pivotals rallying on buying by local funds, dealers said.
The benchmark 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) gained 26.56 points, or 0.90 percent, to a provisional close of 2,985.21, the day's highest level.
Some traders said the government's move to drop a non-voting share proposal also helped buoy market sentiments.
"This is good for the markets as it will send a positive signal to local and overseas investors," said Govind Agarwal, institutional dealer at local brokerage Motilal Oswal.
He said the 3,000 index level will be a major resistance for the market in the next few sessions.
The Economic Times newspaper on Tuesday reported that the government had dropped its proposal to allow companies to issue non-voting shares.
Foreign funds had been opposed to such stock issues because it diluted the value of their holdings.
Dealers said the Unit Trust of India, the country's biggest mutual fund was a major buyer in a number of shares including Hindustan Lever, Bajaj Auto, SBI and TELCO.
Short-covering on the last day of weekly trade at the National Stock Exchange (NSE) added to the gains recorded. The NSE index rose 2 points to 849.05 provisional.
TELCO gained 9.50 rupees to 345.0 rupees, ACC 16.0 to 1,116.0, Bajaj Auto 22.70 to 793.0, TISCO 0.50 to 159.25, M&M 3.25 to 323.50 and Hindalco 11.70 to 618.0.
SBI was unchanged at 218.50 while Reliance lost 0.50 rupees to 194.0 and Gujarat Ambuja Cement 3.25 to 235.50.
